Given the history of the last 4 years and the continuing difficulties (for instance with the bruising), it would be too much to believe that the mother would other than welcome relief from the strain of the present state of affairs. I have nevertheless come to the clear conclusion that whilst that factor is likely to be present, far stronger motivation has been provided by the offer of employment and her deep desire to help her mother and to be with her.

I have then looked at the father's opposition. He sees the long struggle at heavy cost of achieving the present level of contact. His good relationship with C is accepted. He is obviously good with children. All that he considers will come to an end if the mother's application is granted. He cannot continue a valuable relationship with C at a distance of 5,000 miles even if he felt able to visit. He could not afford the visits other than occasionally if he was to take someone else as a protection. His upset at the prospect was so great that he had difficulty in contemplating seeing C even if the mother brought him here.

With the mother now offering staying contact the move contemplated would have an even greater significant effect on his relationship with C. It is a genuine concern that drives the father. C has played a part in his life more profound than even he originally suspected. Any upset to the development of the relationship will cause him considerable upset. He will undoubtedly feel bereft but he argues C will also be the loser as it cannot be in his best interests.

It is his case that the relationship cannot develop at the same rate nor have the same advantage for C which would happen if his parents were both living here and there was regular contact with C. Even if the father took up what I accept is the generous contact offered by the mother, the time between visits and the distance would he believes finish or at least slow down a valuable and developing relationship for C and be contrary to his best interests.
It is an attractive and compelling argument on first consideration. But it overlooks two major factors to which I now come and to which the father has not given sufficient thought or understanding.

The first is the impact on the mother were she not able to go. It would be dramatic and long lasting. All the devastation for her as summarised by Miss Ford are I find genuine and deeply felt. She would have no career to look forward to in her chosen profession and I see no prospect of that changing. She would deeply resent being cut off from her mother when she is so needed. She would be living in a far less desirable home than either she had here or she could provide in the US.

It is idle to believe that this would not affect her care of C. Her frustration and despair would be profound. She would see herself as condemned to remain here without work of her choice solely for the purpose of contact whilst longing to be with her mother in her remaining years. If she succumbed to depression that would not be surprising especially with a continuation of the present level of acrimony with the father as has been rightly predicted. That is a very powerful factor in this case and one of the decisive elements.

But when all these factors are brought into an overview of C's welfare, even if they were not sufficiently clear on their own to justify a relocation for C's benefit (which I consider them to be), there is also the effect on C of the present conflictual situation continuing. I have been totally persuaded by the experts of the increasing harm that will cause emotionally and psychologically for C. I have set out the details. I accept their professional view. It is not something I can ignore. It is again a decisive element.

There is therefore a genuine and strongly reasoned application by the mother to relocate C to the US at a time when I rule out a residence order to the father or at this time a joint residence order. It is also a practical application. The Guardian considers that the mother does have C's best interests at heart. After due reflexion I agree. It is no less genuinely opposed by the father for good reason as he sees it. However the effect on the mother would be as serious as I have encountered in any similar case.

However even if there were any lingering doubts, they would be wholly removed by the seriously negative effect on C of the present situation continuing, which I see again with the expert, has no sign of improving. Given the difficulty for the father in moving on, the intensity of the conflict will remain and be increasingly damaging for C. That outweighs any reduction in the amount and the quality of the father's relationship with him.

It was a consideration of all these factors which enabled me to give a decision at the end of the case. But it does end there. I said I would impose conditions. Before I turn to them, I add some further conclusions.

The father believes that with the mother compelled to stay here their relationship will improve. With the experts I reject that and believe as they do that the only real prospect for improvement is for the mother to be in the US with C for the reasons they give. This includes the reduction in pressure and the stability which will be achieved. The alternative of the mother remaining here without employment in her chosen profession whilst C becomes more damaged by the continuing conflict is far too great a price for C to pay.

Once the father has begun to come to terms with his disappointment and with effective safeguards in place, I consider he will soon for C's sake visit him in the US. This is I find the best and only hope for the developing relationship which the father most wants.

He will retain a good relationship with him in the US supported by regular indirect contact. It will not be as good as regular staying contact here if that could be achieved without the continuing conflict. He has already experienced contact with C in the US. With advantage of cheap air flights he can afford visits if not every 5 weeks at least once every 6 to 8 weeks once it is clear no companion is needed.

With renewed confidence and C's increasing age the father can progress to longer stays both here and in the US. He will not I believe decline these opportunities when he sees its value for C and the pleasure for him. It is because I see with the experts almost no prospect of an absence of conflict here that has led me with my other conclusions to accept the mother's proposals as representing the best chance for the father because it will be the least damaging option for C.

The father has fought valiantly and with the added disadvantage of no representation. I have endeavoured to ensure every point has been put on his behalf. Given the quality and clarity of the expert evidence, I see no prospect of any other conclusion despite the father's great upset. It is unrealistic to think there is any prospect of a sudden or gradual improvement here of his relationship with the mother.

He has not come to terms with the mother's position nor lessened his overriding view that she really wishes him out of C's life. He has had to endure arrests, disruption to contact, and the loss of almost all his resources; it is perhaps understandable that he should view the mother as coaching C. But it underlines why continuing contact here will be fraught with difficulties when each party has by now almost exhausted their emotional strength.

The mother has progressed; sadly it has as yet been too difficult for the father. I am optimistic that this will improve but not whilst C remains in the UK. In the light of the expert's evidence and the telling submissions of Miss Dodson QC and Miss Ford, the real hope for the father's valuable relationship with C is for the mother to move when the pressure for her will be greatly reduced. Her state were she to remain, and the effect on C of both that and continuing acrimony are not in his best interests.

I have looked short, medium and long-term. The short term upset for C of seeing less of his father are heavily outweighed by the prospects for the future with his mother in employment and as I find a substantial reduction in acrimony.

There are 3 conditions in all. The first relates to mirror orders and appropriate undertakings. As the father is not represented I am going to ask the mother's advocate to prepare a draft of what the mother is prepared to offer for the father to consider and on which I can adjudicate.

The second relates to the parents beginning the task of communicating with each other. I regard this as very desirable. The Guardian kindly offered to assist at meetings between them. I await the results.

Finally there is the fund of money represented by the mother's interest in her present flat. The father needs to be reassured that the contact offered will be honoured, and that he can visit and leave Santa Fe without fear of further accusations nor the need to be accompanied. This is so important for C that if a safeguard will promote such visits it should be provided.

What I propose is that the greater part of the proceeds of sale should be held to the order of the court for an initial period to be extended or terminated as required. The percentage to be retained and the length of time have not been the subject of argument. It may well delay the mother purchasing her own property. She may have to rent for longer. But, subject to any argument to the contrary, that should not be too much if it provides the father with added reassurance given the history.
This matter must now be restored for further hearing before the end of term. I should be grateful to have draft orders for consideration beforehand.
